content:
`onload()` is an event handler that is used to execute a piece of JavaScript code when a web page has finished loading. It is a part of the HTML DOM event model, which allows developers to create interactive web pages by responding to user actions and browser events. The `onload()` event handler can be attached to the `window` object or any HTML element, such as an image or a video, using the `onload` attribute. For example: ```php

Welcome to my website

``` In this example, an `onload()` event handler is attached to the `body` element and the `img` element. When the web page finishes loading, the JavaScript code `alert('Page loaded!')` is executed, which displays an alert dialog box with the message "Page loaded!". Similarly, when the `img` element finishes loading, the JavaScript code `alert('Image loaded!')` is executed, which displays an alert dialog box with the message "Image loaded!". The `onload()` event handler is commonly used to perform actions that require the web page or its content to be fully loaded, such as initializing a script or setting up a user interface. By using event handlers like `onload()`, developers can create web pages that provide a rich and dynamic user experience.
